document.docAuthor: Dylewska, M., Błoszyk, J. & Halliday, R. B.
document.docTitle: Platysetosus occultus Dylewska, Bloszyk & Halliday 2006, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Platysetosus occultus gen. nov., sp. nov., a new genus and species of mite from Tasmania (Acari: Uropodina)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Platysetosus occultus gen. nov., sp. nov., a new genus and species of mite from Tasmania (Acari: Uropodina)

Female . Well sclerotised, deep brownish colour.

Dorsal idiosoma (
Fig. 1
). Size range of dorsal shield 500–570 x
350– 400 m
. Idiosoma elliptical, with indistinct broad vertex. Dorsal shield oval, surface with characteristic ornamentation of numerous irregularly shaped pits. Dorsal setae numerous, hair­like.
Marginal shield narrow, with chararacteristic festoon ornamentation; marginal setae simple, short.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1 .
Platysetosus occultus
sp. nov.
, female, dorsal idiosoma.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ventral idiosoma (
Figs. 2
, 3 ). Ventral shields fused and heavily sclerotised. Sternal shield smooth. Four pairs of sternal setae:
st 1 –st 3
short and simple,
st 4
very long;
st 1
located above anterior edge of epigynium;
st 2 –st 4
lateral to epigynium. Epigynium elongate, parallel­sided, with arched anterior and straight posterior margins. Surface of epigynium smooth anteriorly, with characteristic ornamentation in central and posterior areas. Stigmata situated opposite coxae III, with a short hook­like peritreme reaching edge of idiosoma (
Fig. 4
D). Pedofossae present, pedofossae IV oriented transversely, displaced towards podosoma.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Platysetosus occultus
sp. nov.
, female, ventral idiosoma.

FIGURE 3.
Platysetosus occultus
sp. nov.
, female, ventral.

FIGURE 4 .
Platysetosus occultus
sp. nov.
, female. A, hypostome; B, tritosternum; C, setae of palp trochanter; D, peritreme; E, chelicera.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Opisthosoma shortened and covered with characteristic sculpture. Ventral setae diverse in shape and length:
V 1
simple and short;
V 2
hair­like, very long;
V 3
simple; 9–14 pairs of very long, broad and flat setae Vs inserted posteriorly. Submarginal setae Ss simple, short. Anus with one pair of simple adanal setae; unpaired postanal seta Pa absent.

Tritosternum with broad triangular base, lacinia forked distally into four branches; base of tritosternum covered by coxae I (
Fig. 4
B).

Gnathosoma
(
Fig. 4
). Corniculi massive, horn­like. Hypostomal setae simple;
h 1
,
h 3
very long,
h 2
and
h 4
short (
Fig. 4
A). Seta
Pv 1
on palp trochanter simple, short;
Pv 2
very long, serrated midway along its length (
Fig. 4
C).

Chelicera long and narrow; fixed digit of chelicerae longer than the movable digit and angular (
Fig. 4
E).

The name
occultus
(secret, mystery) refers to the fact that we are unable to place this species in any known family of Uropodina .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. Map of Tasmania showing collecting localities for
Platysetosus occultus
sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Platysetosus
is an endemic Tasmanian genus.
P. occultus
has been found at nine localities distributed over most of Tasmania (
Fig. 5
). The genus is characterised by the characteristic sculpture and chaetotaxy of the ventral opisthosoma. In other known species of Uropodina there is no record of the 9–14 pairs of very long flat setae found on the ventral opisthosoma of
P. occultus
. We place
Platysetosus
in the superfamily Uropodoidea Evans, 1972 , but its family placement is unknown. It can not be placed in any of the 36 families of Uropodina listed by
Hirschmann ( 1979 )
. In particular it can not go into the large family Uropodidae because it has claws on leg I. This claw is like that of
Nenteria
, but
Platysetosus
has horn­like corniculae, compared with the digitate corniculae of
Nenteria
. The family­level classification of the Uropodina of
Hirschmann ( 1979 )
is very heavily biased towards the European fauna. When the faunas of Australia and other areas with poorly­known faunas of Uropodina are more fully documented, that classification will need to be completely revised, and unusual genera such as
Platysetosus
will need to be taken into account.

The specimens of
P. occultus
that we have examined are all females (
30 specimens
), and the species would appear to be thelytokous. This is a very rare feature for Uropodina in the Southern Hemisphere.

We have described
P. occultus
on the basis of specimens with 10 pairs of large flattened opisthosomal setae. However, we are aware of the existence of specimens with 9, 10 , 12 , and 14 such setae on one or both sides. The number of such specimens is extremely limited, and the significance of this variation in setal numbers is not known. It may be that more than one species is present, or there could be a single variable species. The answers to these questions must await the collection of more specimens from a greater number of localities. The species appears to favour very wet microhabitats such as moss, in
Nothofagus
forest. Detailed searching of that habitat in different areas of Tasmania should yield the specimens required for a thorough analysis of this group.
